Chapter 6, section 6 on the distinctions of the six [characteristics], the master of that scripture also has doubts about this:
At that time, is this dharma called abiding, called change, or called destruction?
Now I will resolve this.

In the state of having already arisen, abiding, change, and destruction each perform their own function separately, causing the dharma that is characterized to be different from what it was before in one moment, and to have all three meanings.
If it is explained like this, what principle is contradicted?
Therefore the doubts of that [master] are not reasonable.
Moreover, the previous explanation says, even if it is allowed that arising has function in the future, how does it become the future?
It should be explained what the characteristics of the future are.
When a dharma is in the present, the function of arising has already ceased. How does it become the present?
It should be explained what the characteristics of the present are.
This is not contradictory, because there is no present without function.
Isnâ€™t it that when the characteristic of birth arises in the future, it can give rise to dharmas, which is precisely its activity? Why then do you say that this is only present?
O one loved by heaven!
Activity is not what you know. This is a function, not related to activity.
It is said that conditioned dharmas, if able to act as causes and attract their own effects, are called activity;
If able to act as conditions and assist other types of dharmas, this is called function.
As explained before, all present dharmas are able to act as causes and attract their own effects, but not all present dharmas are able to act as conditions and assist other types of dharmas.

It is said that the eye in darkness, or that which has a damaged function, is not able to act as a condition for visual consciousness and assist in its arising. However, its activity is not damaged by darkness, because it can definitely act as a cause and attract future eyes.
Therefore, activity and function are different.
However, in the arising of homogeneous and continuous effects, there is a definite or indefinite power of attraction and guidance, which is called activity and also called function.
If it produces a result in a different class of homogeneous continuation, it merely serves as a condition to assist its arising. This is not its activity but its power.
Isnâ€™t it said in the treatises:
The light of the forbearance and knowledge of dharmas in regard to suffering arises in this way. These three dharmas all have activity in the future.
Oh, our friend!

You now grasp the words and are confused about the meaning. Our school explains that this passage only provisionally establishes activity in terms of the power of a proximate condition. Because it is well established that in the many conditions for the arising of dharmas, this is the proximate condition, therefore the name and concept of activity in the cause in other states is provisionally established in this state. This should be understood in the same way for abiding, etc.

The light of the forbearance of dharmas in regard to suffering also has superior power in this state and is provisionally given this name. In reality, only that which attracts a result is called activity.
Or there is an objection:
If in the state of just arising there is no arising, etc., how is it that at this time arising has activity but abiding, change, and cessation do not?
If birth, etc., exist in this state, how can it be said that birth alone is useful and the others are not?
This objection is not reasonable. In the state of present birth, birth, etc., are not nonexistent. Because the others, abiding, etc., are not present at that time, their functions do not yet exist.

Even if these states do not yet have birth, etc., this is not contradictory, because in your system, when the effect is about to arise, the nature of the producing cause may exist or not exist, because you admit that there are proximate and indirect causes.
Moreover, the author of the Abhidharma-mahÄvibhÄá¹£Ä-Å›Ästra, among the four characteristics, denies difference and says:
Moreover, it should be said that a single dharma, having arisen but not yet destroyed, is called abiding. When it has abided and is about to be destroyed, it is called cessation.
This principle is reasonable.
Difference, with regard to a single dharma, is not reasonable whether examined in terms of advance or retreat.
Why is this?
Difference means the transformation of the nature and characteristics of what precedes and what follows. It is not possible to say that a dharma is different from itself. Therefore, a verse says:
Difference is not established in what is prior, nor in what is different from what is prior, in a single dharma.
Therefore, in one dharma, positing difference is ultimately not established.

Having already briefly established that difference has a separate substance, difference in momentary continuity is not established. Now, each should consider this meaning. That is to say, it is accepted that apart from dharmas there is the substance of the characteristic of difference, by which the characterized single dharma is different yet not different.

This I should consider. Not accepting that apart from dharmas there is the substance of the characteristic of difference, yet accepting that momentary continuity has difference, how can there be difference even though external conditions are without distinction?
The treatise master should consider what I should consider. In the later investigation of the meaning of the three times, it will be clearly revealed.
Now, in this context, it is appropriate to the meaning, and therefore briefly established to dispel doubts.

That is to say, from the beginningless beginning, dharmas only have their own substance abiding, and the function of distinction is non-existent. Due to the power of the conditions arising before and arising together, it causes the function of distinction to arise where it was originally non-existent. This is called the present function, and is also called the ability to attract one's own effect.
On the basis of this, the World Honored One said:
What was originally non-existent now exists, and what existed will again become non-existent.
This function and substance cannot be said to be different, just as the ability to benefit or harm and the ability to experience one's own substance are not different.

Moreover, it is like the grasped [grasping] habitual tendencies attracted by the distinctions of the previous mind in the subsequent mind. This cannot be said to be different from the subsequent mind.
Or, it is like the nature of good, visible, obstructed, and conditioned form, which, although not different from form, still constitutes a category of distinctions.

Therefore, in this regard, the Abhidharma masters establish the name of difference in the distinctions of the substance and function of dharmas, not just in the substance itself, referring to conditioned dharmas.
The function of attracting its own effect in the substance is called abiding, and the decline of this function is called change.
This abiding and decline cannot exist by themselves, and there must be other dharmas that cause abiding and cause decline.
The causes of these two are the characteristics of abiding and change.
Why not accept this correct principle?
We cannot accept this distinction of function in the present time, because it is not of a different nature from its own substance.
Since this function is different, the substance should also be so. Why do you say that the function is different but not the substance?
If one grasps that the substance of the past and future does not exist, one may have this fault in one's tenets, but not one who accepts that the substance of the three times always exists.
Why is this?
If the function ceases, one only abandons the present, and the substance of the dharma still exists. How can one cause the substance to also have a difference?
Therefore, a verse says:
The name of difference in one's own substance is due to the decline of superior function.
How can one establish difference in a single dharma?
In the end, it will not be accomplished.
The present state of arising is not called different, because at that time its function has not yet declined.
Precisely because of this principle, abiding is called different, because it can cause the function of attracting results to decline.
When the activity of a dharma is damaged, it attracts its own effect.
Because the cause is damaged, the effect that arises later is gradually inferior to the previous cause, so the effect gradually becomes inferior.

Because the cause is different, this effect is also caused by the different characteristics that arise together to be damaged. Therefore, it can also be the cause for the gradual inferiority of the later effect.
In this way, the continuity of all conditioned dharmas is made different from the later to the later moment by moment, so the meaning of difference of the previous moments is established.

When this meaning is established, it should be used as an inference. That is to say, because the last [moment] is seen to have a difference, the previous moments definitely have a difference. It is not like the principle of difference in the continuity of moments established by the VijÃ±ÄnavÄdin.
If that is so, when the continuity gradually increases, the difference should not exist, because the effect is not seen.
There is no such fault, because at that time the characteristic of abiding is assisted by external conditions, and its power becomes stronger, subduing the difference.
Other masters say:

The activity of dharmas does not last for more than a single moment. Therefore conditioned dharmas are said to be different. They do not abandon their own characteristics and only then acquire the name of difference. Nor do conditioned dharmas have the fault of having a permanent nature.

Because the nature of dharmas is eternally so, not made, not transformed, and cannot be changed. Therefore fire always uses heat as its essence. Apart from heat, there is no fire essence to be obtained.
However, the activity of fire must rely on many conditions. Therefore the school establishes fire as having an impermanent nature.
If the essence is different, it becomes a separate dharma and should not be impermanent, because its essence does not change.
That is to say, if one only grasps that the present exists and that the past and future do not exist, then the nature of conditioned dharmas should be permanent, because there is no change.
How can there be no difference?
Because existence and nonexistence each have an established nature without change.
They only hold that dharmas of the present moment exist and are immutable. The substance of future and past dharmas does not exist. How can a nonexistent dharma be said to change?

Therefore it cannot be said that created dharmas are impermanent. It cannot be said that nonexistence changes into existence or that existence changes into nonexistence. Existence and nonexistence cannot be established as the substance of change, because existence and nonexistence are mutually contradictory.

Nor is it that the effect is different from the cause, because without a difference in the cause there cannot be a difference in the effect, because the effect must follow the cause in order to be different.

If you say that existence is impermanent, that is not reasonable, because the nature of existence cannot be established as another nature, because the nature of existence of a dharma is never not existent, because existence and nonexistence are established separately.
Consequently, change of created dharmas definitely does not exist, and therefore all created dharmas should be eternal.

If you admit that the past and future both exist and do not exist, then that which is born from nonexistence in the future becomes existent, and that which perishes from existence in the present becomes nonexistent.
The non-determination of past and future existence and present existence not being together is not fixed and can be changed.
The existence of past and future is the same as the present, always without change at all times.

Because the substance exists and the function may or may not exist, it can be said that there are differences in the states of conditioned phenomena. Therefore, only the school that asserts the existence of the three times is discussed.
In a single dharma, it can be said that there are differences. Because the dharma has differences, the characteristic of difference can be established.
Once the characteristic of difference is established, the meaning of impermanence is established.
It is not like the school that only asserts the existence of the present, where the differences between the continuum and the moment do not exist.
As explained before, therefore, one should stop for now.
If arising exists in the future, why don't all future dharmas that are to be produced by arising arise suddenly?
Because their productive causes are always combined.
This has already been discussed.
What was discussed earlier?

That is, there are dharmas that, when they have not yet obtained the function of attracting results, are assisted by external conditions that have not yet been obtained, are obtained, or have already ceased. The power of assistance by internal conditions arises in order to accomplish their own affairs. This is called the characteristic of birth.
Based on this meaning, the following statement is made.
The verse says:
Birth can give rise to what is born, but not apart from the combination of causes and conditions.
The treatise says:
Apart from the combination of the remaining causes and conditions, the power of the characteristic of birth alone cannot give rise to what is born. Therefore, not all future [dharmas] arise suddenly.

Although the characteristic of birth acts as the proximate cause for simultaneous arising and can give rise to what is born, all conditioned dharmas must still rely on the causes of their own kind in the past and the combination of assistance from external conditions, just as the various causes and conditions such as seeds and earth assist the arising of sprouts and cause sprouts to arise.

If this is so, then we see only that causes and conditions have the power to produce, and there is no separate characteristic of production. When causes and conditions come together, dharmas are produced; when they do not, they are not. What need is there for a characteristic of production?
Therefore, there should be only production by the power of causes and conditions.
This criticism is not correct, because the criticism is the same for one who only allows the production of dharmas by the assembly of causes and conditions.

That is to say, if one only allows future dharmas to be produced by the assembly of causes and conditions, this criticism is the same. The causes and conditions of future dharmas are no different. Why do they not arise all at once?
Moreover, when one condition is lacking in the causes and conditions, and the rest are complete, the effect should also be produced.
For example, the eye faculty is attracted by past karma. Even if separated from the great elements, it should still be produced.
Or it should be said that the eye faculty is produced only by the power of the great elements, not by past karma.
Or the eye faculty attracted by karma should always be able to produce the great elements that give rise to it. When one is produced, the others should also arise.

Or else the primary elements have no power with regard to the eye, because the eye is not seen apart from the primary elements, and because the eye is born alone. But the later eye is born only because of the former eye.
If you maintain that the primary elements have the power to produce, then this power is useless.
Also, just as a seed, water, soil, etc., are lacking one by one, and a sprout is necessarily not produced, therefore we know that the power of the seed, etc., is extremely evident.

With regard to the production of the eye, etc., the power of the primary elements of earth, etc., to produce is not evident. Since it is not evident, the primary elements should not be causes producing the eye, etc.
Also, who is the obstacle to the transformation of the continuity of the seeds of karma that you maintain, so that they cannot suddenly produce all karmic fruits?
If the seeds of karma are able to produce only because of the assistance of conditions, then the conditions should be able to produce. What is the use of the seeds of karma?
Because the fruit of karma is produced only when the many conditions assist the seeds of karma, and because if the many conditions are lacking, the fruit is not produced.

Since the seeds of karma are not without existence when they rely on the assistance of conditions, even though they rely on the many conditions, how can you deny the existence of the characteristic of production?

Also, when the first moment of pure dharmas arises, arising can be the cause for the arising of pure attainment. The self-nature of attainment has already been fully established. It should be explained that apart from arising, what other separate dharma can perform this attainment?
If the simultaneous cause is completely absent, attainment should not arise. Then the first pure dharma should not be said to be established.
When the characteristic of arising arises, does it also have a separate simultaneous cause or not?
It should be said that it also exists, namely, apart from the substance of arising, the other one fruit dharma.
How does difference and cessation assist the cause of arising?
Ancient masters all gave this explanation:
Dharmas with the same fruit mutually become causes for each other, just as the four great elements mutually assist each other.
There is also another explanation:
All conditioned dharmas are all the nature of arising, etc.
When each of the four characteristics of arising, etc. is used, through this as the door, the others all assist.
The one who realizes this meaning observes the body, etc. as impermanent in the mindfulness meditation.
However, the elder says:
All conditioned dharmas are without abiding. If conditioned dharmas could abide, they would abide for a very short time.
Why do they not abide for a moment, a day, a month, a year, an eon?
Because there is no other cause.
The scriptures also say that conditioned dharmas have no abiding. As the World Honored One said:
Bhiká¹£us!
All conditioned dharmas are about to perish. Having no abiding, they also have no cessation.
First, their statement that if conditioned dharmas could abide, they would abide for a very short time, is unreasonable.
The very shortest time is one moment. If even one moment has no abiding, then conditioned dharmas would be absolutely nonexistent.

If you say that conditioned dharmas have no abiding at all, because the attainment of their substance immediately perishes, then wouldn't the attainment of their substance be precisely the very shortest time of abiding for conditioned dharmas?
Although there is this time, there is no abiding.
Based on what state do you say that there is no abiding?
Is it at the time of attaining the substance, or after attaining the substance?
If you maintain that the state of nondwelling exists only in the two times, and if there is no dwelling when a dharma obtains its substance, then you cannot escape the errors mentioned above.
If you say that the state of nondwelling exists after a dharma obtains its substance, then this is not acceptable to you, and your criticism is useless.
What you call the time when a dharma obtains its substance is what we call the time when dwelling projects its effect.
We do not maintain that after a dharma projects its effect, it continues to exist. Why do you criticize us?
The time when a dharma dwells is like the time when a dharma exists in your theory. It must be established by the generation and function of other dharmas.
In the same way, that which projects an effect must be established by other dharmas. That which is relied upon is called dwelling.
In that case, our theory is the same as yours. What reason or scriptural authority do you have to contradict us?

Doesnâ€™t a scripture say that dharmas have no dwelling? If you maintain that they do, you contradict this teaching. Your attachment to the existence of dharmas is a variety of speculation and not the true meaning.
What is unreasonable about the explanation of the Abhidharma masters?
The sutra says that there is no abiding in order to refute the idea of permanent abiding.
The next sentence also says that there is no cessation. This statement refutes the idea that conditioned factors are completely annihilated.
If it is not to refute the idea that conditioned factors are completely annihilated, what else does the statement that there is no cessation refute?
However, there are only two kinds of cessation of conditioned factors:
one is cessation without remainder immediately after arising, and the other is complete annihilation.

Therefore, in order to refute the two extremes of permanence and annihilation, the sutra says that conditioned factors have no abiding and no cessation, and it is not to refute the cause established by the Abhidharma masters that causes conditioned factors to abide.

Please consider carefully, you who are wise, who contradicts correct principle and the teachings by saying that conditioned factors have a brief period of abiding or that conditioned factors completely cease to exist?
I did not originally say that conditioned factors completely cease to exist after arising.
Why does the sutra say that when they are about to cease, they also do not cease?
The phrase â€œwithout cessationâ€ means without interruption. This means that when dharmas are born, they necessarily cease without delay, without a momentâ€™s rest.
The phrase â€œwithout abidingâ€ already makes this clear, and to add the phrase â€œwithout cessationâ€ would be redundant.
We do not say that when dharmas are born, they abide forever.
If this is so, why do you say that when dharmas are born, they abide?

The phrase â€œabidingâ€ means temporarily staying. This means that when dharmas are in the process of cessation, they temporarily stay. It cannot be said that they abide when they have already ceased or when they are in the process of being born, because they have no activity. As was said earlier, when dharmas are in the process of cessation, they have the activity of attracting a result.
Even though this is said, abiding definitely does not exist, because there is no sÅ«tra that says that it exists.
Since it is not denied, why do you say that it does not exist?
Also, it must be believed that it exists because it is logically required.
Even if there is no scriptural authority, abiding does not contradict correct reasoning. What is wrong with saying that it exists?
However, there is a definitive teaching that proves that abiding exists, as the Sutra of the Parable of the Hand Clap says:
Bhiká¹£us!
All conditioned things are like illusions, like flames, abiding for a moment, quickly perishing.

How is it not already proven by this that the Abhidharma says that conditioned things have a time of abiding? Because of this, the VibhÄá¹£Ä explanation is also established. The statement that there is no abiding is said with an ulterior intention based on the time after a moment, not that it does not exist at all.
However, what they say, that this is a personal interpretation and speculation that accords with the teachings of the Well-Gone One, because the sÅ«tras never say that there is abiding,

we now say that this type of person has not read this sÅ«tra, or they rely on their own feelings and deny it as being a valid cognition, or they are biased and their minds are disturbed, and even though they repeatedly read the text they do not understand it.
Those who seek the truth are asked to contemplate:
Who among those who follow the Buddha's sÅ«tras personally grasps the statement that conditioned things have a time of abiding, or who denies this sÅ«tra as being a valid cognition?

However, the World-Honored One first spoke in the sutras about the non-abiding of conditioned phenomena at the time of their destruction. Fearing that in the future the UpÄlivÄdins would deny momentary abiding based on those sutra passages, he again spoke this Hand-Clapping Simile Sutra to show that conditioned phenomena have temporary abiding.
They do not accept this teaching of the Great Master and make this criticism:
Why only allow that it is spoken with a hidden meaning based on the moment after, and not say it is based on the subsequent continuity of the same kind?
What difference is there between a moment and this?
This criticism is unreasonable because there is a difference.
Abiding for an instant has the cause of arising together, but abiding for the continuity of the same kind does not have this cause. Therefore this criticism is not reasonable.

They further criticize:ğŸ”½If the power of abiding can cause conditioned phenomena to abide for a while, then why not cause all conditioned phenomena to abide for a period of a thousand koá¹­is of moments?
Why do the causes of conditioned phenomena abiding for one moment not cause them to abide for a thousand koá¹­is of moments?
This is also unreasonable, because they do not admit that dharmas are produced apart from the cause of production.
Why does the cause of the production of dharmas in one moment not produce a thousand or ten thousand moments?
This reasoning applies whether you admit the existence of the characteristics or not.
A scripture says,
You must know that the arising and enduring of pleasant feeling is pleasant.
There is another scripture that says,
You must know that form, etc., has arising and enduring.
If you say that these scriptures refer to a series , this is not correct, because the meaning is not established.
If you do not admit that there is enduring in a moment, how can you establish the meaning of enduring in a series?
Because a series must be established on the basis of moments.
Thus the characteristic of enduring is established by both reasoning and teaching.
But the VaibhÄá¹£ikas insist that it does not exist, and we do not know what enmity we have incurred to make them so stubbornly refuse to accept the obvious truth.
There is another objection:
If the characteristic of impermanence exists as a real entity apart from impermanence, why is there no characteristic of suffering apart from suffering?
Such an analogy is unreasonable.
If you say that the nature of impermanence exists because of the characteristic of impermanence, then you can set forth the objection:
The nature of suffering should also exist because of the characteristic of suffering.

However, the nature of conditioned dharmas is impermanence, and they only cease because of the condition of the characteristic of cessation, just as the nature of conditioned dharmas is impermanence, and they only arise because of the condition of the condition of arising.
In the same way, even if the nature of suffering again has the condition of the characteristic of suffering, what further use is there?
Therefore, the analogy set forth is unreasonable.
This also refutes the objection about emptiness and non-self.
Moreover, the characteristic of impermanence is also the characteristic of suffering, because its essence is impermanent, and because it is explained in the Sutra on Suffering.
Moreover, they should also encounter this kind of objection:

If the dharmas that are produced can only be produced by having separate conditions of production, then one should admit that the dharmas of suffering only become suffering by having separate conditions of suffering.
Or, the dharmas that are produced should naturally arise apart from the conditions of production, just like suffering, etc.
Also, this has been explained previously.
What was explained previously?
If you say that sometimes there is existence in the state of activity, then it must be established by the function of other dharmas.
Thus, in our school, everything always exists, so dharmas have self-nature without depending on conditions.

Suffering, non-self, etc. should be like having self-nature, and cessation should be like arising, only needing other dharmas. Therefore, we know that there is a separate internal cause of cessation, apart from the dharma to be ceased, called the characteristic of impermanence.

If you say that the various activities do not have a separate cause of cessation, arising should also be so, not depending on a cause to exist, because these two are dharmas that are different from the substance.
Or it should be said that there is a cause of the difference between the two.

If you say that these two also have a difference, namely, that the arising of various activities must depend on a cause, it is currently seen that there are differences in speed and slowness when arising.
If the cessation of various activities also depends on a cause, then the time of cessation should also have differences in speed and slowness.
If the time of cessation is slow or fast, then it contradicts the tenet that all activities cease in a moment.
Therefore we know that there is no fault in saying that cessation is spontaneous and without cause, because the cause of cessation must be present at the same time as the activity of the dharma.

Time is not a distinguishing factor, because the cause of arising may or may not be present at the same time as the activity of the dharma, and even though there may be a lapse of time, it still serves as a cause. Therefore the arising of dharmas may be either quick or slow.

If the cessation of dharmas is not caused, then at the moment of arising they would immediately be destroyed, or else they would be indestructible in a later period, because you admit that the later and earlier moments are the same in being without cause.

If you say that at this time the dharmas have not yet arisen and that therefore we are in error in saying that they would immediately cease, then you must admit that arising is the cause of cessation, because cessation is only seen when there is arising.
Since you admit that the cessation of dharmas must await arising, how can you say that cessation is without cause?
Also, we prove that cessation has a cause by means of the teachings. A scripture says,
Because this dharma ceases, that dharma also ceases.
Also, it says,
In this way, all have causes.
Therefore we know that dharmas cease because of causes.

Moreover, the characteristics of conditioned dharmas are mutually causes of each other, because there is cessation only when there is birth, because there is birth only when there is cessation, because there is continuance only when there is change, and because there is change only when there is continuance.
Again, there is an objection:
Because there is no cause of continuance, dharmas perish by themselves. What need is there for a cause of cessation?
This objection is unreasonable, because the theory that only the previously produced is a cause is a theory of the SarvÄstivÄdins, who maintain that the future has no substance.
When the subsequent result is born, the prior cause has already ceased. Even though there is no cause of continuance, why is it not possible for there to be continuance?
Therefore, what they say is not that there is no cause of cessation.

Also, it has already been explained that the characteristic of continuance is the cause. When conditioned dharmas are born, they continue for a moment. How can it be said that continuance has no cause?

If you say that dharmas naturally perish after one moment because they do not exist in a subsequent moment, if there is no characteristic of cessation, what causes their nonexistence? It is because of the characteristic of cessation that dharmas that have been born perish. Therefore, apart from the conditioned, there is a real entity of the characteristic of cessation.
Also, you should not maintain that the real entity of the characteristic of cessation is nonexistent, as a scripture cited earlier says,
â€œThe arising of the conditioned can be known, and its ending and its abiding and changing can be known.â€
It is not that one should be urged to know that which does not exist. That which can be known is a synonym for that which is different.

Also, just as there must be a difference in the power of production that causes the dharma that is produced to reach the state of having been produced, so too must there be a difference in the power of cessation that causes the dharma that is to cease to reach the state of having ceased. Therefore, cessation, like arising, is established as having a separate reality.
Also, the Sthavira says the following:

Although there is no separate existence, oneness, length, shortness, combination, or separation that serve as conditions, one can still establish the existence of one long, short, combined, or separated dharma. Abiding and so forth are also like this, without separate conditions.

This statement would then constitute a fault of contradicting one's own school, because that school itself accepts that there are dharmas such as one, long, short, combined, and separated that are established in dependence on others.

They hold that all dharmas rely on causes and conditions, originally non-existent but now existent, therefore the existence of all dharmas depends on the existence of others, not on the absence of conditions.
Your school holds that all conditioned dharmas originally non-existent now exist, and existence is established only when there is birth.
The Abhidharma masters say that the existence of all dharmas always exists, not dependent on causes and conditions.
Therefore what they say contradicts their own school's doctrine.
Because it excludes other similar things, this one side is established, therefore it also depends on the other one meaning to be established.
Long and short are mutually dependent to be established, or established based on the arrangement of atoms, therefore they do not exist by themselves, they must depend on others to be established.
Union and separation also depend on separate things. Therefore, all things depend on something else. Without depending on something else, names and expressions cannot be established.

Moreover, the cause of the arising of dharmas should also be refuted by this example. Just as the nature of existence does not depend on anything else to be established, arising should also be like this;
But this is not the case. Therefore, the distinctions in states of conditioned dharmas all depend on the causes of change to be established, and do not naturally exist.
Therefore, the characteristics of conditioned dharmas, each in a single moment, all exist separately and truly. The meaning is extremely well-established.

The characteristics of conditioned dharmas such as arising, etc., which are established as nominally existing continua by the DÄrá¹£á¹­Äntikas, do not accord with correct principles and contradict the sÅ«tras;
Only my school accords with the sÅ«tras and conforms to principles. Therefore, the wise should diligently study and practice.
The characteristics of conditioned dharmas have already been extensively distinguished.
What is the meaning of such things as collections of names?
Verse:
The so-called collections of names, etc. are general expressions of concepts, phrases, and letters.
Treatise:
And so on includes the collections of phrases and syllables, because the root text mentions the collections of names, phrases, and syllables.
The general term thought refers to the collection of names, the general term chapter refers to the collection of phrases, and the general term letter refers to the collection of syllables.
The meaning of general term is the meaning of combination, because in the meaning of combination the term uttarÄ is used.
Thought means discriminating attachment to dharmas, and is established in common.
The thought produced by letters is the eye, ear, pot, clothing, carriage, etc.
Such a collection of thoughts is the collection of names, namely, the eye, ear, etc.
A chapter is a chapter that distinguishes.
The worldly treatises explain:
It is the inexhaustible distinction of chapters, which can finally distinguish the meaning that is to be explained, namely, that merit attracts pleasant karmic retribution, etc.
Such a collection of chapters is the collection of phrases, as is said:
Merit attracts pleasant karmic retribution, all desires are as one wishes,
And quickly realize the foremost, eternally tranquil nirvana.
Such are the phrases and so forth.
The letters are the letters A, Ä€, I, Äª, and so forth. Such a collection of letters is precisely a collection of written words, such as Ka, Kha, Ga, and so forth.
Some other masters say: In the Abhidharma treatise, it is said:
What is a collection of many names?
It is said: Names, names and things, and so forth.

The authors of that treatise do not wish to explain that names and so forth are real characteristics, but they ask about the basis of the provisional combination. Therefore, when they ask about a collection of many names and so forth, they definitely should ask about the real characteristics of the substance of names and so forth. In the investigation of the real characteristics of the substance of names and so forth, what use is there to examine the provisional combination of names and so forth?

Moreover, the difference in characteristics of the three, names and so forth, is as follows: That which is manifested by sound and manifests meaning, which has been established together as the definite measure of the expounder, which manifests the self-nature of the known object that arises from the intention that is understood, and which indicates the self-nature of the known object-domain, which is like an echo or reflection, this characteristic is a name.
If one can discern the broad and concise meanings within the known realm, this characteristic is a sentence.
Even when the sound of the speaker has ceased, it still causes one to be mindful and not confused, transmitting it to others. This characteristic is a written text.
Here, name means to follow and go to.
Just as the sound of true words is what is followed, in the same way, names all follow and call out to intrinsic natures.
Sentence means that which can explain the meaning being spoken, that which can discern the meanings of different categories.
Written text means that which can make something manifest, because by relying on this, that is made manifest.
This is precisely the written character, which causes one to be mindful without forgetting, or because of this, it causes one to be without doubt, or it can transmit it to others.
Therefore, some say:

Just as the characteristics of the objects of skillful means of one in meditative concentration are the ladder for the objects realized in meditative concentration, so it is with written texts, names, sentences, and meanings.
Other masters say:
The letters such as a, i, etc., can manifest names and phrases, and are therefore called written form.
These same letters, either separately or collectively, can express intrinsic natures, and are therefore called names.
These same [letters] combined can finally express the distinctions of the various objects, and are therefore called phrases.
In this way, these three kinds should be identical in substance, and should also not be real, and therefore cannot be relied upon.
There are also other masters who manifest the three characteristics in one place, saying:
I know your origin, desire.

Here, the various letters are each called written form, desire is a name, and the combination is called a phrase. This is the general explanation of the aggregates of names, phrases, and written form.
This also does not avoid the previously mentioned errors, and therefore the initially explained three characteristics of names, etc., are good, because they can be investigated.
Aren't the four formless aggregates of feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness generally called names in the sutras?
The Abhidharma treatise also says:
Bodily and verbal karma included in the dharma realm are categorized as form, while the rest of the dharma realm is categorized as name.
Why is it called name here?
It is simply taken as having the nature of the aggregate of dharmas not associated with mind.
Both the scriptures and treatises generally include all dharma gates in two categories:
those with form as their substance are generally called form;
the rest that are not form are generally called name, because the collection of non-form does not include name.
It is generally called name because it is named after the individual.
Here, name only refers to that which manifests the meaning to be expressed, and therefore it is simply taken as having the nature of the aggregate of dharmas not associated with mind.
Is the meaning expressible or inexpressible?
In reality, it should be said that the meaning is inexpressible.
If so, why is it that the word meaning is understood as the same as the word cause, and not understood in a contrary way?
Moreover, it would contradict the sutra, which says:
I will briefly explain the essentials of the Dharma for you.
There is no fault in saying that there is both name and phrase, because they are established by convention.
That is, at the beginning of the eon, people together established various different names for various things. By this means, they transmitted without error the understanding of names and concepts.
Moreover, it is as if there were a saying:
Language is able to issue forth names, and names are able to reveal meaning.
However, a scripture says that the meaning and the words are both excellent, and it never says that there are both meaning and phrases.
Even if we admit that this is so, there is no fault, because the teachings of the World Honored One are endowed with both words and meaning.

That is, the teachings of the World Honored One are able to reveal correctly the innumerable approaches to meaning, and the words and phrases are perfect and complete without any omissions, and for this reason it is said that the meaning and the words are both excellent.
Moreover, dharmas of the three time periods each have names of the three time periods. That is, past dharmas were revealed by past buddhas using past names;
future buddhas will reveal them again using future names;
present buddhas are now revealing them using present names.
It should be known that the same is true for the present and future.
Moreover, among all dharmas there is none that is without a name. If there were, it would result in the fault of being unknowable.
Therefore the BhagavÄn has said the following:
Name can illuminate everything, there is nothing that surpasses name.
Therefore in the one dharma, name is what all follow and act upon.
Other masters say:
Meaning is less and names are more, because within a single meaning there are many names.
Other masters say:
Names are less and meaning is more, because names are subsumed within a single element and a small portion, while meaning is completely subsumed within the eighteen elements.
There are also those who say:

There is a small amount and a large amount in relation to each other. That is to say, in terms of subsuming meaning, meaning is more and names are less. If in terms of establishing teachings, then meaning is less and names are more, because the World-Honored Buddha has established limitless names for each and every dharma according to the meaning.
For example, craving is called love, fire, snake, vine, thirst, net, poison, spring, river, cultivation, vastness, needle and thread, and so on. All are like this.
Here, the author of the treatise says this:
Aren't these three by nature speech, and therefore use sound as their substance, categorized as the nature of form? How can they be said to be mental factors not associated with form?
This criticism is unreasonable.
Why is this?
Because of teachings and principles, we know they exist separately.
The teachings refer to the sutra's statement:
The power of speech and the power of writing.
If writing is speech, what is the point of separate explanation?
It also says:
One should uphold the correct Dharma's written words.
It also says:
Rely on the meaning, not on the words.ğŸ”½It also says:
The cause of the gÄthÄs is the letters of the Chanda. Chanda refers to the measure of the verses, with speech as their substance.
It also says in the sutra:
Know the Dharma, know the meaning.
The Dharma refers to names, etc., the meaning refers to what is expressed.
Another scripture says:
The words and meanings are skillfully wondrous.
It also says:
One should recite the true Dharma with well-spoken words and phrases. The meaning of the true Dharma recited with poorly spoken words and phrases is difficult to understand.
It also says:
The TathÄgata has attained the rare name, phrase, and syllable aggregates.
It also says:
The phrases that accord with various understandings are extremely rare.
Based on these teachings, it is known that there are separate name, phrase, and syllable aggregates that express various meanings, which are real and not provisional, just like the sounds of speech.

Reason means that one is presently seen to sometimes obtain sounds but not obtain letters, and sometimes to obtain letters but not obtain sounds. Therefore it is known that they have separate substances.
As for sometimes obtaining sounds but not obtaining letters, it means that even though one hears sounds, one does not understand the meaning.
It is presently seen that some people roughly hear the speech of others, but then ask again:
What did you say?

This person who hears the sounds of speech but does not understand the meaning is completely due to not yet understanding the written characters that are emitted. How then can one insist that written characters are not different from sounds?
Sometimes one obtains the letters but not the sounds, which means that one understands the meaning without hearing the sounds.
We can see that there are people who do not hear the words of others but know what is being said by seeing the movement of their lips, etc.
This is because those who do not hear the sounds and yet understand the meaning do so entirely by understanding the words that are uttered.
Based on this reasoning, we know that words must be different from sounds.
We also see in the world that people chant spells while keeping the sounds of the spells secret. Therefore, we know that the words of the spells are different from the sounds of the spells.
We also see in the world that there are two debaters, with similar spoken words, one losing and one winning;
The causes of their victory and defeat must exist separately from the sounds.
Moreover, the two unobstructed knowledges of dharmas and language have different objects. Therefore, we know that words are separate from sounds.
Therefore, sounds are merely spoken words, with no difference in characteristics.
Among them, the twists and turns must depend on ka, ca, á¹­a, ta, and pa, etc.

It is necessary that the sounds of speech give rise to the various phonemes, and the various phonemes combine in sequence to produce names. Once these names are produced, they are then able to manifest meaning. Based on this, it is said:
Speech is able to give rise to names, and names are able to manifest meaning. Therefore, the principle that names and sounds are different is extremely well-established.
One should know that in this context, sound is that which can speak, and words are that which are spoken. Meaning is neither of the two. In this way, it is established without confusion.
Here, the author of the treatise also says:
It is not only sounds that are called speech. It is necessary that based on this, the meaning can be understood. Only such sounds are called speech.
This means that the speaker has already established a definite measure for the ability to express meaning.

If the meaning of this sentence can be manifested by names, then the function of manifestation is already explained by just the sounds. Why is it necessary to arbitrarily imagine that there are real names that exist separately?
What are called the definite measures for the ability to express?
Isn't it that the names of thoughts are established in common for meanings? This is then called the definite measure for the ability to express.
That is to say, the speaker first establishes certain characters in relation to certain meanings, and these characters are able to express those meanings in a definite way.
Because of the establishment of these characters, names are produced from these characters, and these names are the definite means of expression.

When the speaker is about to utter speech, he must first contemplate these definite means of expression. Because of this, whether it is his own speech or the speech of others, he is able to understand the meaning that is being expressed.

Therefore, it is not just sound that is able to express meaning. It is necessary for speech to produce characters, and characters in turn produce names. Names are then able to express the meaning that is being spoken of.
Just as speech produces characters, and characters in turn produce names, one should contemplate the principle of producing phrases in the same way.
Here, the author of the treatise says this again:
Moreover, it is not yet understood how these names are produced by speech. Are they manifested by speech, or are they produced by speech?
If they are produced by speech, because speech has the nature of sound, then all sounds should be able to produce names.
If you say that the name is different from the sound, this is sufficient to show the meaning, so why wait for a separate name?
If it is said that the name is manifested by language because language has the nature of sound, then all sounds should be able to manifest the name.
If it is said that the name is manifested by a sound that is different from the sound, this is sufficient to show the meaning, so why wait for a separate name?
The same difficulty applies to the view that sound is able to express.
That is to say, if the essence of sound is able to manifest the meaning, then all sounds should be able to manifest it.
If it is said that the sound that is able to manifest is different, then this difference should be the name itself.
Therefore, the investigation and questioning above are not yet a difficulty.
However, the speaker first stores the desired name in the mind, and then thinks:
I will give rise to such and such words in order to proclaim such and such meaning to others.
Because of this, at a later time he speaks according to his thoughts. The words give rise to the syllables, and the syllables in turn give rise to the name. The name then manifests the meaning.
Because of this process of transmission, it is said that speech produces names and names manifest objects. This establishment of names, etc., is absolutely necessary.
If names are not first stored in the mind, then even if one utters speech, there is no definite indication of meaning, and one cannot cause others to understand the meaning.
Also, the author of the commentary says:
Or, we should only maintain that there is a separate entity called written text, which is collected into the bodies of names, etc. Maintaining that there is anything else is useless.

This is also unreasonable, because there are no written texts that occur simultaneously. Therefore, the idea of a collection is not established, because each written text does not all manifest meaning.

Or, just as trees, etc., are composed of the four great elements, and shadows are not produced separately without depending on them, shadows are produced by the imagination but their substance is not imaginary.
In the same way, names and phrases should be produced separately by the collection of written texts, and those names and phrases are produced by the imagination but their substance is not imaginary.
This is a good explanation, because the principle is well established.
If this is so, then all nominally existent dharmas can be established as really existing.
There is no such error. Why is this?
Because names also exist in a single syllable.
There is no nominally existent dharma that is mixed into a single reality, and therefore the meaning of nominal existence is not similar to that of name.
Since a name can also be obtained in a single syllable, how can one know that this name exists apart from syllables?
In this way, a single syllable, like a meaningless syllable, has nothing to be interpreted. Relying on this as a condition, a separate name arises that is then able to express meaning.
However, they are extremely close, and their separate characteristics are difficult to know, like the two colors of light on a wall that are difficult to distinguish.
If one allows that sound itself is able to manifest meaning, with no separate names, etc., what error is there in this?
Is it not an error to violate the characteristics of dharmas?
There is no sound that can only be obtained by the mind. Syllables, etc., are not like this, and therefore their substance is not the same.

However, there are sounds that are produced by a common agreement, and although one pays attention to them, one only understands the sound and not the meaning. Later, based on this, one can understand the meaning. It is not that one first understands the sound but not the meaning, and later one can only understand the meaning based on this. Therefore, we know that apart from sound there are names, etc. The previous mind did not obtain and did not understand the expressed meaning, but when the later mind obtains it, it can understand the meaning.
If one says it is not so, because the later mind still relies on obtaining the distinctions in sound to understand the meaning,
these distinctions in sound are not different from sound.
This is also not so, because the agreement to express meaning is a distinction in sound, and the principle is not established.

If the common agreement to express meaning is a distinction in sound, then like distinctions in form, which are not established by common agreement, they should still be understandable. The distinctions in the two colors blue and yellow must be established by common agreement before they can be understood.

Although no common agreement is established in advance regarding the distinction between the two colors, the characteristics of the distinctions between blue and yellow are not different from color, so when the eye consciousness obtains them, the mental consciousness can immediately distinguish and discriminate the distinctions between them.

Moreover, it is not reasonable to make another agreement on top of an agreement, so it should not be said that it can express an agreement.ğŸ”½Although it is not different from sound, if no common agreement is established in advance, even if one obtains sound, one still needs to wait for others to establish an agreement, so one is still unable to understand the distinctions between this and that sound.

Moreover, if the established agreement is a distinction in sound, then the distinctions between meaningful and meaningless sounds, although no common agreement regarding the distinctions was established in advance, one should still be able to understand them, meaning that there are these distinctions in one sound but these distinctions are absent in other sounds.

When one hears the two sounds for the first time, although one does not understand their meaning, one should be able to understand the difference between the sound with a contract and the sound without a contract, just as one can distinguish the difference between the two colors.
Therefore, we know that apart from sound there are separately existing name, phrase, and syllable, which arise in dependence on sound and are able to manifest meaning.
However, the Sthavira says this again:
The sound that arises first from mental action, the arrangement of the letters that are determined and distinguished, forms names, etc.
This separate self-nature apart from sound cannot be obtained.

In this way, it should be shown by the previous principles and teachings that the Sthavira has words but no reality, and it is not only by his empty words that he is able to immediately establish that sound is the substance of names, etc.

If it is only by his empty words that he is able to immediately establish that sound is the substance of names, etc., then he should also be able to establish that all dharmas that are generally recognized as having separate substances are without separate substances.
Namely, the nature of moisture, when accumulated and solidified, is called the nature of solidity;ğŸ”½That very nature of solidity, when dispersed and melted, is called the nature of moisture;
The nature of solidity and moisture, when separated from coldness, is called the nature of warmth;
The above three natures, when light and moving, are called the nature of motion;
The form realm cognized by the eye consciousness is included in the olfactory sphere;
The great elements that can be the object of cognition are called mind and mental factors. In this way, everything should be able to be established.

Moreover, the characteristics of fragrance, touch, etc. that are currently shaken by causes can also understand the meaning. Therefore, it is not appropriate to establish the three aggregates of name, phrase, and syllable as having sound as their essence. Therefore, in my explanation, there are names, etc. apart from sound that can manifest the principles of the meaning.
If one can truly manifest a little bit of what is not, I should accept it, not just be swayed by their empty words that are unable to overturn the true meaning.
Moreover, although they say:

As the World Honored One said, speech is caused by investigation and discernment, not by non-investigation and non-discernment. Because sound produces sound, the three of name, etc. have no separate substance, this is also not a mistake, because of giving, etc.
That is to say, as the sutra says:
Abandoning giving, receiving happiness.
This should also be so, speech is caused by name, speech;
Also like contact, etc., caused by, is also called contact, etc.

Also, although they say that the aggregates of name, phrase, and syllable are not known in the world to be mental activities, I will speak on them. Since they are not known in common, what basis does speech rely on to arise?
This is also unreasonable, because although the world does not discern their power, they are able to be objects.
As the world says:
Burned by vegetables, rotten by mud.
Although they do not understand, they are able to be objects. This should also be so.
Also, as with the eyes, one directly sees light, and says, I now see but do not understand form.
Moreover, the sound of clapping one's hands is the cause, and it is said to make a sound, not to make a clap.
Moreover, the ignorant only say:
The cause of abandoning desire is abandoning, which then defiles.
However, in reality, the cause of abandoning desire is the birth of the path of abandoning, which can give rise to the mind of wind, and the mind again gives rise to wind, and the wind then abandons.

Thus, there is no lack of the understanding of names, etc., that can understand the meaning, but it is because the characteristics of the understanding of names, etc., are subtle that one cannot know them.

Although the indeterminate mind cannot distinguish this is the understanding of sound, this is the understanding of names, etc., and this is the understanding of meaning, it is not actually non-existent. Therefore, when carefully examining the characteristics of the distinctions of dharmas, the coarse speech produced by the worldly mind is not sufficient as evidence.
Moreover, the world is also unable to know the realm of experience of self-realized wisdom, and therefore the World-Honored Buddha has explained it as it truly is.
All those who grasp the self and so forth, all arise only from the five aggregates that are taken up.

In the same way, if one does not hear explanations of coarse and shallow matters, one is still unable to understand them, much less the name, phrase, and syllable groups included in the aggregate of mental activities that are not directly associated with the mind. Without relying on explanations, one is unable to understand them. Therefore, what they say is definitely unreasonable.
Moreover, the author of the treatise says:
The momentary sounds cannot be accumulated, and there is also no single dharma that gradually arises in parts. How can it be said that names are produced by language?
He also explains himself:
How does it rely on the past moments of expression?
The last moment of expression can produce the non-manifest.
He also questions himself:
If so, then the sound only produces the name in the last stage, and hearing only the last sound should be able to understand the meaning.

If one makes this assertion that language can produce writing, and writing further produces names, and names then manifest the meaning, the error in this should be the same as what was explained before, because the moments of writing cannot be accumulated.
The error of language manifesting names should be the same as production.
Moreover, if the written word is manifested or produced by speech, then speech must be manifested or produced by name, but this is unreasonable.

This objection contradicts their own tenets, for they say that past and future do not exist by self-nature. Since the prior and subsequent moments of sound cannot be produced all at once, how can they form written words, names, and phrases?
If the prior moments of sound are mutually supported, and the last moment forms written words, names, and phrases, then hearing only the last moment should make the meaning understood.
Moreover, there is no mutual support, because past and future do not exist.
If there is only one moment, how can there be mutual support?
If there is no mutual support, then prior and subsequent moments are similar. The last moment should be unable to express meaning, just like the first moment.
Hearing the last moment should not make the meaning understood, just like the first moment.
Therefore, their assertion that sound can express meaning through mutual support between prior and subsequent moments is not established.
Our school holds that the three times all exist and are not nonexistent. Therefore, the later depends on the prior to produce names, etc.

Although the last moment of thought is called name and so on, if one only hears that, one cannot understand the meaning, because one does not hear the complete agreement to establish names and so on that can produce sound.
However, there are those who understand by hearing one sound, because of familiarity.
Based on this, the rest are inferred. Therefore, the author of the treatise says that refuting that is not this.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say that names, phrases, and syllables each have three kinds.
The three kinds of names are names, name aggregates, and multiple name aggregates.
Phrases and syllables are also like this.
Names have many states, arising from one syllable, two syllables, or many syllables.
For those arising from one syllable, when one syllable is spoken, there is only name. When two syllables are spoken, it is called a name aggregate.
Some say:
When three syllables are spoken, it is called a multiple name aggregate.
Some say:
When four syllables are spoken, it is called a multiple name aggregate.
For those arising from two syllables, when two syllables are spoken, there is only name;
When four characters are spoken, it is called a name-group.
Some say:
When six characters are spoken, it is called a group of many names.
Some say:
Only when eight characters are spoken is it called a group of many names.
As for the production of many characters, when three characters are produced, when three characters are spoken, there is only a name. When six characters are spoken, it is called a name-group.
Some say:
When nine characters are spoken, it is called a group of many names.
Some say:
Only when twelve characters are spoken is it called a group of many names.
Because this is the door, the production of many characters and many groups of names should be explained according to reason.
Phrases also have many states, namely middle phrases, first phrases, last phrases, short phrases, and long phrases.
If a phrase is produced by eight characters, it is called a middle phrase, because it is neither long nor short.
That is to say, a middle phrase is produced by thirty-two characters, and four such phrases form a Å›loka. The compositions of sÅ«tras and Å›Ästras often follow this number.
If it arises from more than six but less than twenty-six letters, it is called a subsequent phrase.
If it arises from less than six letters, it is called a short phrase, and if it arises from more than twenty-six letters, it is called a long phrase.
For the time being, we rely on a medium phrase to explain the three kinds. When eight letters are spoken, there can only be a phrase. When sixteen letters are spoken, it is called a phrase-aggregate.
Some say:
When twenty-four letters are spoken, it is called a multiple phrase-aggregate.
Some say:
When thirty-two letters are spoken, it is called a multiple phrase-aggregate.
Because a syllable is just a letter, there is only one position.
When one letter is spoken, there can only be a syllable. When two letters are spoken, it is called a syllable-aggregate.
Some say:
When three letters are spoken, it is called a multiple syllable-aggregate.
Some say:
When four letters are spoken, it is called a multiple syllable-aggregate.
For this reason, it should be said:
When one syllable is spoken, there is a name, but no name-group or many name-groups, no phrase, no phrase-group or many phrase-groups, and a syllable, but no syllable-group or many syllable-groups.
When two syllables are spoken, there is a name, and a name-group, but no many name-groups, no three of phrase, etc., and a syllable, and a syllable-group, but no many syllable-groups.
When four syllables are spoken, there are three of name, etc., and no three of phrase, etc., and three of syllable, etc.
When eight syllables are spoken, there are three of name, etc., and a phrase, but no phrase-group or many phrase-groups, and three of syllable, etc.
When sixteen syllables are spoken, there are three of name, etc., and a phrase and a phrase-group, but no many phrase-groups, and three of syllable, etc.
When thirty-two syllables are spoken, the three of name, phrase, and syllable each have three kinds.
Through this as the gateway, the rest is explained according to reason.
Having briefly discussed the three, one should further contemplate:
Are name, etc., bound to any realm?
Are they sentient beings or not?
Are they born of retribution, or are they nourished, or are they of the same kind?
Are they good, bad, or indeterminate?
All of this should be discussed.
The verse says:
Name, etc., belong to the desire and form realms, are of the same kind, and are indeterminate.
The treatise says:
These three, name, etc., are only bound to the two realms of desire and form.
Within the form realm, some say they exist only in the first dhyÄna stage, while some say they also extend to the upper three dhyÄnas, because they are bound separately according to speech and body.

If it is said that these three are bound according to speech, then when one born in the desire realm speaks the language of the desire realm, the speech, name, and body are all bound to the desire realm.
The meaning they express may be bound to the three realms or may not be bound.

When one in the first trance state speaks the language of the first trance state, the speech and name, etc., are bound to the first trance state, and the body is bound to the desire realm. The meaning is as explained above.
In this way, if one is born in the first trance state and speaks the language of two stages, one should contemplate according to reason.
If one is born in the second, third, or fourth trance states and speaks the language of two stages, one should also contemplate according to reason.

If one says that these three are bound to the body, it means that one is born in the desire realm or the four trance states. The name, etc., and the body are each bound to their own stage, and the speech is either bound to its own stage or to another stage. The meaning is as explained above.
Moreover, the three of name, etc., are included in sentient beings, because insentient dharmas and conditioned dharmas do not accomplish them.
The speaker accomplishes them, not the expressed meaning. One only accomplishes the present, not the past or future.
Moreover, the three of name, etc., are only of the nature of outflow, not of nourishment, and not of retribution.
As for saying that name, etc., arise from karma, it is because they are the dominant effect produced by karma.

Also, name, phrase, and syllable are only categorized as non-defiled and indeterminate. Therefore, when those who have severed wholesome roots speak wholesome dharmas, although they accomplish wholesome names, etc., they do not accomplish wholesome dharmas.
Those who are free from craving for desire do not accomplish unwholesome [dharmas].
Those who are post-learners do not accomplish defiled [dharmas]. They accomplish the names, etc. that can be expressed, but not the dharmas that are to be expressed.
The remaining meanings of non-associated compositional factors that have not been explained will now be briefly discussed.
Verse:
Homogeneous character is also like this, and also the formless realm's karmic maturation,
Attainment, characteristics, and the three categories, non-attainment, meditative absorption, etc. are the outflow of causes.
Commentary:

The phrase also like this is used to show that homogeneous character, like name, phrase, etc., is common to the desire realm, form realm, sentient beings, etc., the outflow of causes, non-defiled, and indeterminate.
The phrase and also the formless realm shows that it is not only in the desire realm and form realm.
The phrase and also karmic maturation shows that it is not only the outflow of causes.
This is the meaning of the three categories and two types of causes.
What is karmic maturation?
It refers to the homogeneity of the destinies of hell beings, etc., and of those born from eggs, etc.
What is the homogeneity of the same moral quality?
It refers to the homogeneity of the realms, stages, and sense bases, of the various castes and classes, of Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as, of those in training and those beyond training, etc.
Other masters say:

Among the various homogeneities, that which is produced by the power of previous karma is the homogeneity of retribution. That which is produced by present practice is the homogeneity of the same moral quality. Attainment and its various characteristics are of three kinds: that is, they are momentary, of the same moral quality, and of retribution.

Non-attainment and the two samÄdhis are only of the same moral quality.ğŸ”½The word â€œonlyâ€ is used to clarify that they are not of retribution, etc. The rest should be explained, but it is not explained because the meaning can be understood by analogy with what has been explained before.
